Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement from having technology at one's disposal to forgo travel-- yet develops no remorse or regret. River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to Universal’s Gothic aesthetic. Allen Dwan directs the film with passion and desire; he presents everything his audience could possibly want from an action-drama set in 1860s New Zealand.

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is clearly an attempt to create a Jackie Chan character but has just as much humor, bad dubbing (though this isn’t so noticeable if you’re not concentrating), and martial arts with semi-funny but also a bit annoying John Barrymore Jr . playing Benji the dog.
